repnme.cdata!: Moldova - Promoting sustainable growth and competitiveness

abstracts.cdata!:
This report talks about the promoting
            sustainable growth and competitiveness in Moldova. Facing
            the need for a sustainable growth strategy, Moldova has been
            working with the International Development Association (IDA)
            to address its main development challenges through increased
            economic competitiveness, promotion of human development and
            social inclusion, and increased effectiveness of the public sector.

docna.cdata!: Moldova - Promoting sustainable growth and competitiveness

display_title.display_title:
Moldova - Promoting sustainable
            growth and competitiveness

repnme.cdata!: Moldova - Rural Investment and Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural Investment and
            Services Project for Moldova were as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was significant;
            Bank performance was satisfactory; and the Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Lessons learned include:
            conditions attached to projects, particularly those bearing
            on sector development policy, should be proportionate to
            project scale; otherwise, they should be consigned to other
            operations. Credit agreements and project budgets should be
            sufficiently flexible to allow for changes in project
            financial intermediaries during implementation. A grant
            element was included in the credit line for enterprise
            start-ups in order to accommodate businesses with weaker
            collateral. But, in practice, the same collateral
            requirements were applied, whether or not a grant was
            attached to the loan. Credit lines involving multiple
            sub-loans require a considerable delegation of fiduciary
            responsibility. Providing consulting services to help small
            entrepreneurs prepare and implement business plans is as
            critical for the success of rural finance programs as
            providing long-term credit.

docna.cdata!: Moldova - Rural Investment and Services Project

Moldova - Rural Investment and

            SERVICES PROJECT,TF052123-MOLDOVA RURAL INVESTMENT AND
            SERVICES PROJECT,TF051987-JSDF SEED-MOLDOVA:
            COMMUNITY-BASED LAND AND WATER RESTORATION,TF030313-CANADIAN CTF FOR CENTRAL AND

repnme.cdata!: Moldova - Rural Investment and Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            were substantial, achieved through satisfactory performances
            by both the Bank and Borrower. Lessons address the
            following: 1) On broad policy issues, conditionalities
            should be very limited in investment lending operations,
            limited to policies that affected the project directly. For
            example, further disbursement to savings and credit
            associations should not have been allowed until there was a
            proper supervisory authority in place. As much as possible,
            further "policy issues" should be integrated into
            alternative documents. 2) On Rural Finance, credit lines
            that are likely to make a large number of small sub-loans
            need considerable delegation of fiduciary responsibilities.
            While eligibility criteria for participating financial
            institutions should be designed during project preparation,
            the project should allow for some flexibility to
            add/subtract financial intermediaries throughout project
            implementation. Loan documents AND budgets should allow this
            flexibility. If the credit line is going to contain a grant
            portion, the project should ensure there is a general
            consensus on the constrain the grant is trying to address,
            so that the project can objectively measure its
            effectiveness. 3) On advisory and business development
            services, the lack of consulting services to help small
            entrepreneurs prepare and implement business plans, was as
            important a constrain to rural finance, as the lack of
            long-term credit on the market.

repnme.cdata!: Moldova - Rural Investment and Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Rural Support
            Services Development Program Project is to provide long-term
            support to accelerate agricultural recovery and growth so
            that Moldova's agricultural sector can play its full
            role in providing the underpinnings for future income growth
            and poverty reduction. There are three main project
            components plus support for project management. The first
            component provides the most essential information to
            emerging private farmers. The second component creates
            legally registered rural businesses with business plans. The
            third component provides finance to bankable rural clients.
            The first two components provide predominantly technical
            assistance, while the third component provides private
            investment support along with the necessary technical
            assistance to participating financial institutions. The
            first three components are closely linked, with each
            dependent on the others for successful outcomes.

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Rural Investment and Services
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            RISP details negative environmental impacts and measures to
            mitigate them. High standard phytosanitary requirements ,
            adequate packaging, and compliance with bilateral agreements
            will ensure that pests and diseases and diseased animals and
            animal products will not be introduced in export. Staff will
            be trained in proper handling methods, appropriate storage
            of fuels and lubricants, and periodic safe transfer to
            recycling facilities will reduce soil contamination and
            water pollution. Safety equipment and clothing will be
            issued and on-site warnings given to avoid personal
            injuries. Loss of aquatic ecosystems and resources will be
            prevented by appropriately handling and storing pesticides,
            fertilizers, and waste materials. Also, farmers will be
            trained in appropriate application levels. And the
            timeliness of applications. The importance of the ecosystem
            from where irrigated water will be sourced will reduce the
            loss of water systems through irrigation. Traditional plant
            varieties and indigenous and endemic germplasm will be
            protected. Crop rotation with legumes and green manures will
            avert heavy dependence on fertilizers. There will likely be
            some nutrient leaching from chemicals into surface waters
            and into groundwater sources as well as nutrient enrichment
            of the soil. Effective air emission controls will be deployed.
